title: DPMC: Weighted Model Counting by Dynamic Programming on Project-Join TreesWork supported in part by NSF grants IIS-1527668, CCF-1704883, IIS-1830549, and DMS-1547433.

sections.empirical evaluation:
We are interested in the following experimental research questions, where we aim to answer each research question with an experiment. In the planning phase, how do constraint-satisfaction heuristics compare to tree-decomposition solvers? In the execution phase, how do ADDs compare to tensors as the underlying data structure? Are project-join-tree-based weighted model counters competitive with state-of-the-art tools? To answer RQ1, we build two implementations of the planning phase: HTB (for Heuristic Tree Builder, based on [ref]26) and LG (for Line Graph, based on [ref]25).
HTB implements Algorithm 1 and so is representative of the constraint-satisfaction approach.
HTB contains implementations of four clustering heuristics (BE-List, BE-Tree, BM-List, and BM-Tree) and nine cluster-variable-order heuristics (Random, MCS, InvMCS, LexP, InvLexP, LexM, InvLexM, MinFill, and InvMinFill).
LG implements Algorithm 2 and so is representative of the tree-decomposition approach.
In order to find tree decompositions, LG leverages three state-of-the-art heuristic tree-decomposition solvers: FlowCutter , htd , and Tamaki .
These solvers are all anytime, meaning that LG never halts but continues to produce better and better project-join trees when given additional time.
On the other hand, HTB produces a single project-join tree.
We compare these implementations on the planning phase in Section 6.1. To answer RQ2, we build two implementations of the execution phase: DMC (for Diagram Model Counter, based on [ref]26) and tensor (based on [ref]25).
DMC uses ADDs as the underlying data structure with CUDD .
tensor uses tensors as the underlying data structure with NumPy .
We compare these implementations on the execution phase in Section 6.2.
Since LG is an anytime tool, each execution tool must additionally determine the best time to terminate LG and begin performing the valuation.
We explore options for this in Section 6.2. To answer RQ3, we combine each implementation of the planning phase and each implementation of the execution phase to produce model counters that use project-join trees.
We then compare these model counters with the state-of-the-art tools Cachet , c2d 9, d4 , and miniC2D  in Section 6.3. We use a set of 1976 literal-weighted model counting benchmarks from [ref]26.
These benchmarks were gathered from two sources.
First, the Bayes class333https://www.cs.rochester.edu/u/kautz/Cachet/ModelÀôCountingÀôBenchmarks
consists of 1080 CNF benchmarks444excluding 11 benchmarks double-counted by [ref]26
that encode Bayesian inference problems .
All literal weights in this class are between 0 and 1. Second, the Non-Bayes class555http://www.cril.univ-artois.fr/KC/benchmarks.html
consists of 896 CNF benchmarks666including 73 benchmarks missed by [ref]26
that are divided into eight families: Bounded Model Checking (BMC), Circuit, Configuration, Handmade, Planning, Quantitative Information Flow (QIF), Random, and Scheduling 5   .
All Non-Bayes benchmarks are originally unweighted.
As we focus in this work on weighted model counting, we generate weights for these benchmarks.
Each variable xùë•x is randomly assigned literal weights: either Wx‚Äã({x})=0.5subscriptùëäùë•ùë•0.5W_{x}(\left\{x\right\})=0.5 and Wx‚Äã(‚àÖ)=1.5subscriptùëäùë•1.5W_{x}(\varnothing)=1.5, or Wx‚Äã({x})=1.5subscriptùëäùë•ùë•1.5W_{x}(\left\{x\right\})=1.5 and Wx‚Äã(‚àÖ)=0.5subscriptùëäùë•0.5W_{x}(\varnothing)=0.5.
Generating weights in this particular fashion results in a reasonably low amount of floating-point underflow and overflow for all model counters.
 We ran all experiments on single CPU cores of a Linux cluster with Xeon E5-2650v2 processors (2.60-GHz) and 30 GB of memory.
All code, benchmarks, and experimental data are available in a public repository (https://github.com/vardigroup/DPMC).
